creditline: The Christina N. and Swan J. Turnblad Memorial Fund
department: Chinese, South and Southeast Asian Art
description: A yogini bearing a jar.  One of 19 known sculptures from a set originating in Kanchipuram, Tamil Nadu, India.
text: This powerful, life-size female figure is a goddess known as a yogini.  Hindu devotees worshipped yoginis as embodiments of female energy (Shakti), an energy that could be as ferocious as it was benevolent.  Our yogini was once enshrined in a circular, open-air temple with at least 15 other goddesses.  She has four arms, indicating her divine statusâ€”her upper arms might hold a jar of medicine and spatula, suggesting her curative capabilities. Her now broken bottom left arm would have held an outstretched skull cup for drinking liquor or blood. Yoginis were believed to possess powers of flight, to which the lightly incised bird underneath her right foot might allude.
title: Yogini with a Jar
